I often see language in abortion debates like "some claim that the heart beats 18 days after conception" like there's some kind of great mystery here. There is a mystery, two actually: 1. How this easily verifiable fact can be treated like some unknowable assertion and 2. how the little fetus, mostly just a tube of undifferentiated stem cells (at that point) , can have a beating heart.
Actually, the hearts just an amazing mystery all around. It starts beating 18 days after conception but doesn't functionally pump blood until you take your first breath after being born. After that first beat, it goes on beating, all on its own, until you die. It never stops, never cramps up, never takes a break.
I'm not a creationist, but it's easy to say with the Psalm writer that we are fearfully and wonderfully made.

Not trying to be a party-pooper here, but I'm wondering about the ethics around using live embryos as a exhibit display. Are these embryos developed to full-term chicks and hatched (I doubt it, but happy to be shown otherwise)? Or are they destroyed and replaced each day so that you continue to have embryos in each development phase for part of the exhibit? Somehow I feel like this is less ethically justified for what is essentially human entertainment than using and disposing of embryos for study and science. The educational purpose of this display could be achieved with a single video of one embryo's development, rather than having multiple live specimens. That would be a lot less awe-inspiring, sure, but it would also be a lot less wasteful.

Curious to hear your thoughts, Destin, as well as others' as well! Again, I'm not trying to discredit the display; I'm sure a lot of intelligent people thought really hard about it before going through with it. I'm only trying to instigate a friendly critical thought discussion <3

I teach this "egg window into life" lab to local grade schools and my pre-med and grad students. It is miraculous and more complex than we will understand, but simple enough to do at home.
1) Purchase fertilized eggs, and a simple heat lamp incubator from your local feed and seed, with some Microscope cover-slips, rubbing alcohol and a paraffin candle for the egg window.
2) carefully take an egg and sterilize one side of the shell with rubbing alcohol The window needs to be on the side of the egg, not the top. Note that the eggshell is both the lungs and kidneys for the developing chick. It needs to be handled gently. The chick will not develop without the shell.
3) (the hard part) CAREFULLY snip, nibble and chip a small shallow window in the side of the eggshell using a needle, exact o knife blade etc. the Window must be no deeper than the width of the shell, and completely covered by the cover-slip.
4) place the cover-slip over the hole and gently hold it against the shell, then seal the edges by dripping melted wax from the candle around the edges of the cover slip to seal out air and infection. Again, the Egg shell is the lungs for the chick, and controls the amount of O2 and CO2 for the chick. Room air has too much CO2 and will make the inside of the egg acidic.
5) return the egg to the incubator with the cover-slip window up. The yolk and baby chick will naturally orient and float to the highest surface under the cover-slip window, so you can watch the chicks development over time. The fluid dynamics of the ovalbumin, yolk and shell are miraculous physics.
If your school has a stereo-microscope capable of 100X , you will be able to see the blood flow within the arteries and veins, liver lungs and pancreas as they develop. Time laps pictures of the developing chick are awesome . Most importantly, the camera for viewing through the egg window is best stabilized using the vistibular- ocular reflex of an adult chicken. Simply attach the camera to the chicken's head and place her over the developing chicks. She will watch the chicks for you ...(Huge Smile) Thank You once again fro excellent content., Helping our schools is developing our nations most important resource, Our Kids.

Hey Destin. Have you ever 'hypnotized' a chicken? It's interesting until you aunt finds all the chickens staring at the ground.

Take their head and tuck it under their wing. Pick them up facing away from you (facing out, same way you are), make big circles in front of you as if they were in a front loading washer/dryer (don't flip them, just make the big circle). Do this for about 5 - 10 circles. Put them down on the ground, but don't let go. Hold their beak to the ground, gently, and draw a wavy line (like a worm) out from the beak and then let go. They will just stare at the line and not move. When you want them to move, just clap your hands or make a loud noise close to them.

In school I loved cellular biology, and I still do, but the deeper we got into the rabbit hole the more I formed a love-hate relationship with biology. It's a pain to study, sure, but that isn't the reason. I love it because it is simply amazing and absolutely mind blowing how everything works, within 1 cell alone, then you go deeper and see how the nucleus works on its own and it's even more insane, you go deeper and switch your thinking form "ok, this is just a chromosome" to "these are chains of ATOMS, MOLECULES, things that just exist and now form these hypercomplex structures and forms, and you're telling me they can DETECT ERRORS IN THE DNA/RNA SEQUENCE AND FIX IT??!!", and that I hate, because it's INSANE to think about how it's even possible that all this stuff works. In an ant colony or our society things work because each group are given a task, we understand it, and comply with it, but then there are these lifeless miniscule "balls" of condensed energy who just join others into comparatively huge chains and.. they work the same as if someone or something is giving orders, but... there is no high command centre.. as far as I know at least, and that's what breaks me. I want to KNOW, I cannot accept that it just works that way just like that. One teacher only gave me a theory a coworker of his worked on, about intricate micro-electromagnetism or something in that direction, which.. ok, I can imagine that with just a couple of atoms or small molecules, but then you think back at the ridiculously organized chaos that's going on inside a cell, think that into a 3D perspective and no, I giggle at the absurdly complex nature of.. well, nature. I love it, but I hate it

It's kind of hard to imagine how quickly this is happening at the molecular level.  Let's say the embryo is .1mL on day 5 and is 70% water.  That's .07g of water and .03g of 'stuff'.  If the 'stuff' is mostly proteins, at 40kDa avg per protein, we're looking at (.03g / 40,000 g mol) = 7.5e-7 moles of protein.  That times Avogadro's number (6.022e23) gives us ~400 quadrillion individual proteins that have been assembled into an enormous array of functional structures in ~100 hrs.  The actual answer is waaaaay more complicated than that of course, but that's a ballpark figure.

I manage the breeder department for a major commercial Poultry Integrator in the US.  You can actually visually tell if an egg is fertile much earlier than the “Day 1” they had on display. Next time you break an egg you can see for yourself!

Random fun fact: Incubation doesn't actually have to start the day the egg is laid. The embryo can lay dormant for up to two weeks without being Incubated and still hatch, though the longer you wait the less viable it is. Many farmers (including me) save up their eggs for a week before beginning Incubation. But once you start keeping the egg warm, you can't stop.
I've always enjoyed watching my eggs develop but haven't been able to see what happens in detail or in the first week before. The only way I get to watch it is by shining a light through the shell in a dark room. (This process is called candling) but the shell is thick enough that you can't see anything inside until they've been incubating for a week.

Fun fact: one of the genes activated during this time is the Sonic Hedgehog (SHH) gene. It tells the body what "left, right" and "up, down" are. SHH mutations/ disruptions (i.e. from heavy metal or environmental toxins) can make 4 legged frogs or 4 winged chickens. This is also why pregnant women can't take some drugs since they can affect how the SHH gene work and cause severe birth defects.
